Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A portable, powered lift to instantly increase independence of all manual wheelchair users
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the increased independence, productivity, and quality of life of people who use wheelchairs. This project addresses important national and worldwide challenges related to the mobility of people who use wheelchairs (4 million in the US alone), which is continuously jeopardized by many daily challenges. Through the development of an affordable and ready-to-use aftermarket accessory capable of increasing the height of manual wheelchairs, the project is oriented towards a more equal, inclusive, and accessible society. The proposed technology will dramatically boost the self-confidence of people who use wheelchairs by enabling face-to-face conversations and improving their productivity at work. It will increase their independence by allowing them to reach surfaces and spaces that were previously out of their reach. At the same time, the new solution will reduce injuries resulting from tips and falls due to unsafe reaching from their wheelchair. Users will save costs associated with injuries and expensive home retrofits. Finally, the proposed technology will represent a huge opportunity for employers because of increased productivity for their workers with disabilities and dramatically reduced costs adapting the work environment and providing "reasonable accommodations", as required by law.

The proposed project seeks to explore the feasibility of solving height-related problems among all people who use manual wheelchairs with an electronic and affordable device that can be retrofitted on all standard ultralight wheelchairs, balancing crucial factors such as weight, height of lift, and ease of operation. The proposed Phase I activities will generate the first functioning prototype capable of serving as a proof-of-concept for testing and future commercialization. Engineering efforts will be first dedicated to the selection and integration of hardware components and to the development and deployment of the device control software. A sensor-based control scheme will be implemented to enable a safe, smooth, and fast lift experience. Once the hardware is assembled and the firmware is deployed, the new device will be tested in laboratory settings to ensure that, when it is attached to a standard wheelchair, it does not alter the wheelchair's stability. This is an essential prerequisite not only for future FDA approval, but also to make the device ready for future testing (Phase II) with volunteers and, more generally, to enable its commercialization as a universal aftermarket accessory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The concluded SBIR Phase I project was focused on the assessment of the technical and commercial feasibility of the Levate Wheelchair Lift (LWL), a lightweight, attachable aftermarket accessory for manual wheelchairs designed to solve reach-related difficulties that daily challenge the independence of wheelchairs users.

A first prototype was developed satisfying the major design specifications of weight, lift maximum load and time, de-risking the most significant technological challenges associated with the project. Electronics hardware was selected and designed, and the firmware for wireless control developed. Final, tests showed a total lift extension of 21 inches, lift time of 5.5 seconds and a lifting load of 330 lb. A total of 30 lifts were accomplished using a single 30 Watt-hour battery.

The design of the LWL brought to the development of an innovative linkage system, similar to a Watt’s link, which maintains perfect parallelism of the upper and lower joints, with insignificant lateral displacement granting stability and safety to the structure. An attachment bracket and a docking system were ideated to allow attachment of the lift to the wheelchair. The bracket consists of an axle and two pins, one of which is stationary while the other can move up and down, while the docking system was designed to operate as a tractor-trailer 5th wheel. To provide stability in any direction the landing gear was modelled to wrap around the footprint of the pivoting front wheels.

The Integrate Circuit components for the LWL control system were identified in the Atmel ATMega2560 IC, a high-performance, low-power Microchip 8-bit AVR RISC microcontroller. The printed circuit board schematic on which the IC is mounted was developed with a lean approach, using the Proteus software.

The firmware design was focused on communications between the end-user and the Levaté Lift and centered on Bluetooth connectivity and the relative application for both iOS and Android device apps. The Bluetooth module selection developed in this Phase I project is not yet final and will be finalized during NSF-SBIR Phase II. At the moment is constituted by a DSD Tech SH-HC-08/SH-M08 module, a 4.0 Low Energy (BTLE) UART device.

Laboratory testing to attest stability and safety of the developed prototype was performed. With the test operator seated on the wheelchair, a total lift extension of 21 inches was measured exceeding our milestone goal of 10-12 inches. Lifting time was recorded as 5.5 seconds for both ascent and descent. Powered lifting load testing was also conducted to verify that the expected limit load of 280lbs could be lifted, lifting limit was reached at 330 lb.

To test the stability of the system the operator raised the wheelchair to maximum height and then extended his limbs as far as possible in every direction to ensure tipping would not occur and the chair was stable. Other stability tests included measuring the tipping angle and measurement of the peak force required to tilt over the wheelchair with a simulated user.

Battery endurance testing was done at a temperature of 50° F with a fully charged 18V 1.5 Amp‑hr battery. The testing showed that 30 lifts could be accomplished using a single 30 Watt-hour battery.

The result of this Phase I SBIR project is a novel concept that will dramatically improve the state of the art of solutions for height-related problems that wheelchair users face with an affordable aftermarket accessory that can be retrofitted to all existing manual wheelchairs. LWL will allow wheelchair users to maintain their independence, increasing self-confidence and Quality of life (QoL). The QoL of wheelchair users is associated with the ability to perform activities of daily living (ADL, feeding, bathing, dressing, and grooming) and instrumental activities of daily living (IADL, transportation, shopping, cooking, doing laundry and doing housework). To overcome ADL–IADL limitations, wheelchair users need to have expensive home accommodations ($20K) and constantly ask for help. Levaté will enable wheelchair users to reduce at a minimum home retrofitting, saving money, and will also reduce the need for help in outside settings, allowing to easily reach out for items stored in “eLevatéd” positions thus generating a sense of empowerment. Levaté will bridge the gap between the disabled and the able-bodied population. Participation in the labor force is generally reduced for people with disabilities, in particular, only 20% of the wheelchair users are involved in the American labor force compared to 70% of the abled people. Levaté will provide a way to reduce this difference, giving the possibility to wheelchair users to access a wider range of working options, making the execution of the assigned tasks easier and allowing increased confidence from having eye to eye conversations with colleagues and management. Levaté will offer employers a disruptive solution to increase productivity for their workers with disabilities, reducing the costs to adapt the work environment to provide “reasonable accommodations”, as required by ADA law.
